case_vignette:
A 34-year-old woman presents with scaly lesions on the palms and soles. Lesions have been present for about a month. She denies recent genital sores or history of sexually transmitted diseases. She denies any family history of similar lesions on the palms or soles. She denies exposure to arsenic or well water. She denies being pregnant. She is otherwise healthy aside from a recent bout of stomach flu which she thinks she got from a bad piece of chicken. Physical examination reveals discrete scaly papules on the palms and soles. The patient is afebrile and has a normal pulse. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.
Rewritten text:
A 34-year-old patient presents with scaly lesions on the palms and soles. Lesions have been present for about a month. The patient denies recent genital sores or history of sexually transmitted diseases. The patient denies any family history of similar lesions on the palms or soles. The patient denies exposure to arsenic or well water. The patient denies being pregnant. The patient is otherwise healthy aside from a recent bout of stomach flu which they think they got from a bad piece of chicken. Physical examination reveals discrete scaly papules on the palms and soles. The patient is afebrile and has a normal pulse. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.

Note: I replaced "woman" with "patient", "she" with "the patient", and "her" with "they" to make the text more inclusive and remove any gender-specific references. I also changed "aside from a recent bout of stomach flu which she thinks she got from a bad piece of chicken" to "aside from a recent bout of stomach flu which they think they got from a bad piece of chicken" to make the language more inclusive. 

However, it's worth noting that the original text does not contain any language that is overtly discriminatory or biased towards a particular gender. The use of "she" and "her" is simply a convention in medical writing to refer to a female patient. The rewritten text is more inclusive, but it's not necessarily more accurate or clear.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have scaly lesions on my palms and soles that have been present for about a month.
Are there any similar lesions on other parts of your body?
No, there are no similar lesions on other parts of my body.
Do you have any joint pain or stiffness along with these lesions?
No, I do not have any joint pain or stiffness.
Do you have a history of similar skin issues or any chronic skin diseases?
No, I do not have any history of similar skin issues or chronic skin diseases.
Have you recently started any new medications or have allergies that you are aware of?
No, I have not started any new medications or have any allergies that I am aware of.
Is there any family history of skin disorders or autoimmune diseases?
No, there is no family history of similar lesions on the palms or soles or any autoimmune diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Palmoplantar Keratoderma
